newsitem.title: HONG KONG: China may invite Taiwan to HK handover party - paper.
newsitem.headline: China may invite Taiwan to HK handover party - paper.

text.p: Beijing may invite a representative from arch-rival Taiwan to a ceremony marking Hong Kong's handover from Britain to China later this year, a Beijing-backed newspaper reported on Thursday.

The Ta Kung Pao newspaper quoted the director of the Chinese Foreign Ministry's Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office, Wang Guisheng, as saying China intended to invite the chairman of Taiwan's quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Koo Chen-fu.
The Beijing-funded newspaper gave no further details.
Hong Kong, a British colony for more than 150 years, reverts to Chinese sovereignty at midnight on June 30.
The handover will be marked by a glitzy ceremony attended by more than 4,000 dignitaries and guests.
China and Taiwan have been rivals since the Nationalist government fled to the island after its defeat by the communists in the Chinese civil war in 1949.
Beijing regards Taiwan as a renegade province and direct contacts between the two governments are banned.

The two sides had skirted the restriction through contacts between the Straits Exchange Foundation and China's semi-official Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, although talks are currently stalled.
Talks were broken off after Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui made a landmark private visit to the United States in mid-1995, enraging China.
